title: Combining Text (String Concatenation)
simplifierConcept:
Sometimes you want to combine pieces of text, like combining 'Hello' and 'World' into 'Hello World'. This is called STRING CONCATENATION (fancy word for 'gluing text together').

In C#, you can combine text using the + operator:

"Hello" + " " + "World" becomes "Hello World"

You can also mix text and numbers! C# automatically converts numbers to text when you use +.

Think of + as glue – it sticks pieces of text together into one long piece!

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: The + operator glues text together. Make sure there's a space between words, or they'll stick together like 'HelloWorld'!
When you add text and a number, C# converts the number to text first. "I am " + 25 becomes "I am 25".
Parentheses matter! "Result: " + 2 + 2 gives "Result: 22" (text gluing), but "Result: " + (2 + 2) gives "Result: 4" (math first).

challenge.instructions:
Create a personalized greeting card! Use string concatenation (+) to combine:

1. A greeting: 'Hello' + [a name]
2. A message: 'You have completed' + [a number] + 'lessons!'
3. An encouragement: 'Keep going, you are doing' + [an adjective] + '!'

Make it your own!
challenge.hint: Remember to add spaces! "Hello"+"World" becomes "HelloWorld". Use "Hello "+" World" for proper spacing!
commonStickingPoints: Forgetting spaces between words: "Hello"+"World" becomes "HelloWorld" instead of "Hello World"!
Mixing up (2+2) vs 2+2 in text: Without parentheses, C# glues text instead of doing math first!
Forgetting quotes around text: Console.WriteLine(Hello + World); won't work – they need quotes!
